Magi is, according to numerous lists, one of the very best adventure anime of all time. If that is the perception of the majority of the community I'd definitely argue this show is considerably overrated. That being said, while it certainly is not without flaws, which I'll be addressing shortly, it's an overall GOOD show, though in my opinion not a GREAT one, and it's probably worth a look for fans of the genre.
Art-
This anime is fine visually, but, considering it's a modern anime (2012) it really isn't anything special compared to other products of its time. What you get here is pretty run ofthe mill for a non low budget anime from this time period. I cannot think of any scenes that blew me away visually but the anime isn't ever ugly either. Some of the characters have ridiculous designs, but this is a deliberate decision.


Sound-


In my opinion the single strongest element of the show is it's phenomenal background music, which I'd rate a slam dunk 10/10. It was varied, it was scene appropriate and it was very high quality. Environmental scenes had beautiful Arabian sounding music that perfectly fit the locale. Battle scenes had uptempo, evocative music that always felt like it was integrated masterfully into the scene. Sad moments had dramatic, sullen music to really fit the mood. 


A side note that really impresses me about the music is the fact that it felt like the music was actually designed to be background music, which feels uncommon in anime these days. Often times a song is designed to be, well, a song, and they simply cut it and play part of it in the background of whatever scene. In this case it felt like the music was designed specifically to fit the scenes as opposed to being intended to be listened to after the fact as a standalone product and they really nailed it.


After all those compliments, here's some negativity to counteract it- As lovely as the background music was, the voice acting was very average. None of the important characters have accompanying standout voice performances and some of the less important characters, villains in particular, have super cringe inducing, blatantly over the top, ridiculous voices. 


A somewhat disturbing pattern I noticed is that several of the villains have voices, and sometimes appearances, that came damn near the line of outright mockery of a stereotypical homosexual person. It felt like the director or the person in charge of casting the voice actors was making a point to get a dig in at that community, which is something I don't support or appreciate at all. One male villain who was blatantly afeminine and wore lipstick and such had a voice that bordered on degrading and likewise a different male villain- a character clearly designed to come off as a jerk and be disliked- had a massive lisp and talked in an odd and potentially suggestive way. If these implications were intentional, shame on them.


Character/Story-


The characters are likely the weakest part of Magi as they are, in one word, flat. Character development is lacking in this anime in a big way, which is exasperated by the fairly large size of the cast, and damn near every single character doesn't really have anything more to them than basic emotions and however they appear on the surface. I found it very difficult to connect with or care about any of the characters and none of the moments that were intended to be emotional effected me at all, as I simply didn't care.


This anime also suffers from pacing issues and perhaps a bit of misleading advertising. For such a highly regarded ADVENTURE anime there really isn't all that much adventure to be had. Many stretches are slow, boring and very dialogue heavy and the middle section of the show is significantly overly drawn out. I thought, based on the synopsis of the anime, I'd be watching a group of characters go from location to location attempting to capture dungeons and obtain the power within, which is a premise I was definitely into, but in reality once the characters leave the initial dungeon in the third or fourth episode they do not return to one again until episode 19, which is a very long stretch of much less exciting things. The fact that the characters only go inside TWO dungeons over a 25 episode stretch was definitely a letdown. 


Also, this anime has a bit of an identity crisis and perhaps isn't self-aware of the way it comes off. There are many childish moments and immature boob references, but then all of a sudden it tries to get really dark. It was very difficult to take the dark moments seriously when the character development was sorely lacking and when the large majority of the show was, clearly, aimed at a young teenage audience. Another thing that worked against the dark moments is that this show is way too afraid to kill off any remotely important characters. Even in its final battle in which in two separate locations a major conflict is occurring- one with 8 good guy generals (many of whom are undeveloped and unimportant) facing off against the army of the bad guys and the other where the main characters fight against a super villain- every single person on the side of the good guys survives and the good guys claim a decisive victory without any consequences or meaningful casualties. The sense of inevitability that the good guys will always win and the main cast of three will, no matter what, absolutely survive through the show and be fine really detracted from any sense of danger or consequence.


Enjoyment-


I didn't specifically dislike watching Magi, and it finished really strong with its final 5 ish episodes being quite good and getting me back into it, but overall I was fairly disappointed given how hyped this show is. If not for the strong final few episodes I'd have given the show a 6. The premise of capturing dungeons in a magic-heavy land is super underutilized and as I mentioned previously the middle section in particular really dragged and got into a very dialogue heavy political type situation, which is not what I want from an adventure anime.


I'm glad I watched the show and I will watch season 2 in the coming months but there is just no way this show is one of the best adventure anime of all time as I've read so many times.


Overall-


First of all, overrated. More specifically, an interesting but definitely underutilized premise, average voice acting, flat/underdeveloped characters, pacing issues in the middle, ineffective tone shifts and a major case of "the good guys will always win no matter what" syndrome backed up by lovely environmental music, a few cool but over the top battle scenes and too many immature scenes that were probably trying, and failing, to be humorous.


Worth a watch but NOT an all time great.


+Some of the best background/environmental music I've ever heard

+Great concept/premise

+Solid battle scenes


-Flat/underdeveloped characters

-Pacing issues

-Tone issues

-No sense of danger or consequence because, no matter what, the good guys will be okay


OBJECTIVE RATING- Weak 7

PERSONAL ENJOYMENT RATING- Strong 6/Weak 7

Despite being a shounen series at heart, actual fights in Magi tend to stay on the sidelines in comparison to plot and character development, which is a refreshing take on the genre. The main characters were quite endearing right from the first episode, while the support cast of characters were very likable too.
With the arcs taking place in different parts of the fictional world, it is interesting to see the various cultures in play, along with their own goals and motives. A shame that with only 25 episodes, the plot did feel rushed at points when the lore itself could have enjoyed a closer examination.This is most evident when the show hit a climax during the Balbadd arc, while spending the next few episodes trying to build itself back up for the conclusion.


The dynamic between Alibaba, Aladdin and Morgiana was what kept me glued to the series, the show did well in exhibiting their growth as characters, as well as justifying their decisions. But just as you would identify with the protagonists, you are just as likely to sympathize with the villains too, thanks to the generous amount of screen time in explaining their history.


If there was anything worthy of nitpicking, it would have been the sound and music. The "rukh" sound effects were way overused and had little variation, while the same voice clips of hounds were used in two separate episodes too to my annoyance. Music wasn't anything to write home about either, when most of them were ambient and unmemorable.


This animated adaption did deviate from its manga source at points, but it did its best in covering the central story, along with most of the branches. I would recommend a read through of the source material before watching, though it isn't essential.


In my final summary, hearing "Alibaba-kun" uttered by Aladdin for the first time was strangely jarring yet weirdly appropriate, this sums up my feeling towards this show perfectly. Fans of the shounen genre should give this show a chance.

Magi: The Labyrinth of Magic was a great ride. If anything, it succeeded very well as a shounen and magic anime. Since most Shounen anime consist of friendships, comedy, ecchi, brave and strong characters, and, of course, fights to keep you at the edge of your seat, it's mostly very enjoyable. I have to say that Magi took all those components and put an equal amount of it in the show, so there was a lot going in it when I watched it. I am a HUGE fan of magic, so of course I thought of giving this show a shot, and magic alwayshas it's own concept or system in different animes so I was confident that I would like it. And I was impressed, unlike most anime that I've seen, Magi: The Labyrinth of Magic was really fun to watch and whilst I mostly never rate anime due to how much I enjoyed it, this one passed.


Story-8

Well, you could just read the summary and get a small insight into the story and what Magi: The Labyrinth of Magic is about. We've got Magi, incredibly rare yet classy and ancient-known magicians. It's common knowledge that there are only, or should be, 3 Magi that exist in the world simultaneously. After they die, 3 new Magi are born (or something, none of that is actually specified). But then we have cute 10 year old Aladdin, a 4th Magi. It's still a mystery whether this Magi should exist or not, but there he is, our MC. For ten years, he lived alone, somewhere where he was isolated. Aladdin only had the company of a "Djinn", namely Ugo. Aladdin asks of him to be his friend and he can summon Ugo from his flute. Aladdin wants to explore the world, which is understandable after being alone and trapped for 10 years. He wants to get out, learn more about himself, who he really is and how the world works. Sooner or later, he meets a 17-year old boy Alibaba, who he befriends very quickly and they both pretty much started to get along well. Aladdin causes destruction of some supply cart and Alibaba is responsible to pay for it. He doesn't have the money (being very poor) so he enters a dungeon along with Aladdin, and after that, well.. the adventure gets pretty damn crazy. A lot happens, Alibaba gets his own Djinn, too.

Well, this anime actually has a heavy amount of politics and rebelling. If anything, we go deep into the personal lives of many characters and that just makes you love them more. It might be hard to understand some parts and such in both the Balbadd and Sindria arc but the best you can do is try paying a lot more attention. Other than that, it's really enjoyable. Each fight is something I could watch whole heartedly, and I've laughed a bunch seeing Alibaba and Aladdin's messed up chibis and their pervertedness. There's a lot of feels in this show too, it kind of gets depressing at times and sometimes the show takes you as far as to make you sympathise with a lot of characters. It's definitely got a little, or a lot of comedy, fan service, battles etc.

We also have the concept of how Magic works in this show. Each living person has a supply of "Magoi" in them, it's like a life source, just like Nen from Hunter x Hunter. It's energy which is generated from something called "Rukh" which I will get to later. If you run out of it, you die. You can recharge, though. The only way for humans to actually use the Magoi is through specials weapons called Vessels. There are many types of them, and you have to concentrate your Magoi into them to transmute your Magoi into, well, it depends on each individual. We also have Rukh, and it's known as Magoi's most major source and the "natural phenomenon of the world". Rukh is known to guide people, people who can accept their fate which is already drawn out from the beginning. Of course, it's not accepted by everybody, and so they do not have Rukh, but "Black Rukh". Black Rukh is originated from hatred or resentment. It can be possible to reverse fate with Black Rukh, too. There is a lot more to all this but it's much better to understand all this in the show.


Art-7

I liked the art style. Simple and cute (yes I said cute), it's very similar to other anime like Toradora! too. I loved how each supporting and main character had a unique design to themselves, and you'll see for yourselves. 


Animation-7

The animation of Magi: The Labyrinth of Magic is certainly the weakest point of the show. Even though it's not bad, the animation during fights are splendid, that I'll tell you, but normally it's very weird.. I don't think I can describe it, but human movements and all that seem unnatural. I mean, I know this is anime but I'm comparing to other anime too.


Sound-8

Oh I swear, Dansing Bizarre was seriously the coolest Arabian-themed OST I have ever heard. I'll be honest here, ALL of the OSTs were good in this show, they just seemed to match everything so, so nicely. We also have the first opening which has made it's way onto my most favourite opening of all times ;u; 

The voice-acting was very good! At least Aladdin sounded like a kid, that's a relief.


Characters-10

Really good.There were so many characters in this anime, they all were just so freaking awesome! All of them had a different design, personality and a lot more to themselves. Morgiana, Aladdin and Alibaba made really good MCs for this show, Sinbad, the Eight Generals, Cassim and almost everybody else. I really don't want to say this buuut.. I didn't even dislike any of the characters, at all! 

I do want to write a lot more about the characters in this anime but if I did, I think you'd get spoiled, a lot. So I'll stop now.


I enjoyed this anime so much, I don't even want to critic against it and point out all of it's flaws because it was just that good. I recommend you watch this anime if you're a fan of Shounen and Magic, you wouldn't regret it, that I know.

After a long hiatus I am back to writing reviews, and this time I’ll be looking at one of those friendship conquers everything anime, Magi: The Labyrinth of Magic. 
The story takes place in an imaginary world based on the medieval Middle East, which is unique in its own right, but sadly that has to be the only unique thing about this anime. We are introduced to our two main protagonists who by a series of encounters, become good friend and embark on an adventure. All of that sound all nice and fun, and I have to say it was a lot of fun towatch, but at no point did it manage to pull me in. The story starts to evolve after the first arc, and I have to say it does improve in many aspects, and tackles many themes rarely found in anime, but unfortunately it was always too predictable and cliche, there was never any suspense, and one could immediately know that friendship will prevail in the end. One thing I have to praise is the pacing as it was surprisingly consistent, and even though there were 25 episodes overall filler episodes were nowhere to be seen. The ending was also done as good as the rest of the story would permit, but overall it was one of the best conclusions I have seen in a while, while still feeling like a great starting point for the second season.


Our main characters are Aladdin, Alibaba and a bit later on they are joined by Morgiana. Alibaba is our generic main character, he is everything one expects of a hero in a shounen anime. Even so he gets some character development, and his backstory is deeply explored, which is laudable. Next up we have Aladdin, who is this little kid with some serious magical powers, and the ability to summon a giant jinn named Ugo to fight for him. Other than his powers he usually acts like a normal careless kid, but at times he becomes a sort of voice of reason in the group. The best character in the show has to be Morgiana, a former slave saved by our dynamic duo, to form a tenacious trio. She gets her fair share of development as she faces the demons left over from the years she spent enslaved. She is also a fearsome fighter and proves to be an invaluable member of the group. Throughout the series, several side characters are introduced, and they are almost always great additions to the story. The antagonists in the show are plentiful and fleshed out really well, but unfortunately they never seem like much of a threat.


The main attraction of the anime has to be the animation, it is positively amazing. The colour palette just pops out, but unlike anime like No Game, No Life it isn't overly aggressive. The scenery is exceptional as well, the world really looks like it jumped out of the 1001 Night, with the beautiful desert landscapes and the arabic architecture. The character are also done unbelievably well, the movement is smooth and the facial expressions flawless. Here I have to point out Morgiana, who has to be one of the best drawn female characters I have seen in a while. We do have a bit of fan-service here and there, but it is never overbearing, and does not distract from the story.


The sound was in my opinion at list mildly disappointing, both the openings and endings were mediocre at best, and won’t find their way into my iTunes library anytime soon. The rest of the soundtrack was adequate, but at no point rising to more than decent. Lastly I would like to touch upon the voice acing, as it was the first time I was bothered by the Japanese pronunciation of non Japanese names so much, that I actually started watching the dub. Would it be really so hard for them to find character names that were actually pronounceable in the Japanese language?


All in all the anime was an enjoying watch, but not much more than that. The pacing and the art were great, but unfortunately that alone can not pull the anime out of mediocrity, and so I give it a low 7. I am unable to wholeheartedly recommend it everyone, but if you are looking some light anime to watch, and are not bothered by predictability, this might be the right anime for you. 

I always appreciate some feedback as so my future reviews can be even better, also if you enjoyed this review feel free to check out my other reviews.

Magi is a well orchestrated shounen anime with a gripping fantasy world that really sucks you in. After taking various settings and characters from the 1000 and 1 Arabian Nights stories, and combining in with a rich fantasy world has created a setting that is unique and full of detail detail that feels real. The story of Magi set within this world is rich with character development and fantastic storey arcs that start with idea of the main characters exploring, and conquering a Labyrinth a mystical tower that holds riches and legendary djinn, which is what Aladdin and Alibaba set out to after the firstfew episodes, but what follows after is a roller-coaster of gripping narrative that successfully links each story arc without you knowing.


Each arc is well crafted to advance the main characters development as well as carry different themes they posses from slavery to discrimination and finally to fate. These themes are well crafted into the story, which helps bring serious events into fruition through good character interactions and well done fights. But we must remember that this is a Shounen so the outcome of most of the fights are predictable and tend to end in the same way which can be a little annoying but doesn't ruin the experience as much, as it could have done.

By the end of the series your left feeling amazed and ready for more; even though the end ends in a cliffhanger there is a second season which is a great relieve.


As said before each arc mainly centres around one character and usually runs through that character's back-story that caused great emotional reaction within myself thanks to, each back-story featuring dark and depressing themes; whereas other main characters are kept more as side kicks but they are still essential to the plot and help that leading character on there journey.


But leading from this, I would just like to say that the characters in this show are great, they are well designed having interesting appearances that are unique in one way but also bear resemblance to characters in 100 and 1 Arabian Nights, this helps create some truly fantasy looking characters. But this could also be said about the characters personalities as well with main characters Aladdin, Alibaba and Morgiana having unforgettable and unique personalities that don't feel cliché, but not only that they all get great development over the course of the series that makes you feel like they actually grow as people.

But this is not kept just by the mains as supporting characters are surprisingly well done having great appearances and personalities that makes each individual feel unique and fit into their role very well, from the cool king Sinbad to the greedy, tyrannical king Abhmad and beyond, these characters are one of the main focuses of why this world truly shines.




The art used in this anime is fairly good, having a great art style that fits the show nicely and good animation which creates great fights sequences and overall character movement though the mouth animation can look a bit odd at times.

The soundtrack is the most prominent part of the series as it simply beautiful with each track mixing in well with every available theme and scene in the anime. The opening is great as well - well at least the first one as it captures the sense of adventure within the show while showing a great opening animation that feels the same well while the second opening didn't do as much for me although the second opening animation was still great to watch and the ending songs I only listened to once and never listened to again as they weren't exciting or fun to watch.


In conclusion you should match this, Magi is a great show with amazing story, characters and soundtrack with only a one animation problems, some uninteresting ending songs and its demographic holding it back. It is a must see that is unforgettable and unique.

tl;dr: I find this show to be generic, cliche and tropy. The characters behave more like generic anime characters than real people, which negatively impacts the political story line. The dialog is awkward and stilted, while consistently using the crutch of explaining everything as a form of constant exposition. The themes regarding destiny/fate are confused and many of the situations are hard to swallow as believable. 
I recognize that this show is very popular and well liked, which is why I was originally interested in watching this show. I love 1001 Nights and the aesthetic that goes with it, so it seemed like a goodfit for me. I have actually watched this show before, when the season was first released and decided to read most of the manga (before ultimately dropping it), but my feelings on the show are... complex. I wish there were a rating for just "setting" as that is really the only thing I actually like about this anime. I find that the later storylines pick up some of the slack and the story DOES improve somewhat, but not within this season.


As far as shounen anime go, this is a fine place for any shounen fans to go. I would say that it's in league with shows like Naruto or Dragon Ball. That is, however, as far as my recommendation goes. I imagine that if I had watched this as a kid, I would have loved the anime. It has a great inspiration, the setting is interesting, and it has all those shounen gimmicks for an action/adventure show that any kid would love. If you are looking for a shounen series, this show is passable. 


However, I wasn't looking for a shounen series, I think I was looking for something more a long the lines of Fullmetal Alchemist Brotherhood in quality. I don't particularly like shounen as an adult and I don't think that this show does anything to escape the trappings of the genre. I also, fundamentally disagree with the idea that anime should continue to follow these tired and obnoxious tropes. I don't think that "shounen" is an excuse for cliche.


The characters are pretty basic anime tropes that do nothing to escape that trapping. They are the same characters you have seen in a hundred anime. The show itself is cliche, predictable, tropy and it does nothing to separate itself from every other shounen. I am actually shocked that this series has such high ratings, because of just how unambitious it is. It is sterotypical anime down to its core. The dialog is awkward at best and absurd at worst. People don't talk or behave like people, they behave like parodies of anime characters. I find the dialog and writing to be embarrassing and cringy; I haven no other words to describe it. You have people CONSTANTLY explaining what they are doing, as if the audience is too stupid to figure it out. It runs into that issue where battles come to a complete stop so that the characters can narrate what they are doing, which is unnecessary and something I particularly hate. It violates the classic concept of "show, don't tell" every chance it gets. Possibly due to translation, but the dialog itself comes off as incredibly unnatural. Not just because they are constantly explaining what's happening, but because the show seems more interested in fulfilling shounen check boxes than it does illustrating a believable world, inspired by 1001 nights. The characters, their actions, and the way they talk are all ridiculous and in some instances, unbelievable. The villains are so petty and obvious that it's impossible to take them seriously. The heroes are just... anime heroes. 


The story itself is passable. It's nothing special and only works because of the interesting setting that the writer put together. I love the ideas of dungeons and Magi and the Arabic aesthetic. However, I think the presence of sterotypical anime characters and ridiculous plot tropes really only drags the compelling setting down. You have these political scenarios, which sound interesting on paper, but are executed to a degree of absurdity. These nations don't behave or interact like real world nations, they behave and act like, well, anime characters. In shows like Gurren Laggan, it works, because of how wonderfully absurd and stylized the story is. In this, they try to play it too straight for it to be believable. Compare it to the political events of central in Fullmetal Alchemist or the tense political scenario of 08th MS Team. In the latter, the political situation is believable, consistent, and has a thread of realism that makes the situations feel dire and tense. In Magi, it just feels... made up. There are multiple moments in the show that just seem overly simplistic and unlikely. 


Beyond the fact that I find this show to be intensely generic, unrealistic, and cliche, Magi is also built around some ridiculous themes regarding destiny. Without spoiling anything, the end of the first season builds up this theme that I just cannot get behind. The themes of Magi are only believable within the context of the show and are not translatable to reality. That is at least, if you take the story in the first season at face value. I think that the themes become more reasonable in the second series, as more information is provided, but at the very least I would say that themes are confused. Specifically, I am referring to the show's position on the concept of fate. The theme honestly feels inconsistent, which leads to this conflicting opinion on it. There are moments in the show that almost seem to imply that "going against fate is bad", which is ridiculous and one reason I detest the show. But... then the actual mechanics of the concepts of fate become fleshed out and the theme begins to take a turn. But I would almost argue that the inconsistent perspective of faith has more to do with providing the good guys opportunities to be in the right, rather than any solid stance on the concept. Either way I find the themes to range from dumb at worst to confused at best. 


At the end of the day, this show is just another shounen anime that doesn't do anything to evolve the genre. There are too many anime that use shounen tropes as skeleton to make something unambitious, cliche, and generic. I don't like these tropes and they hold the genre back. Just because an adventure series is aimed at young adults, doesn't mean that they have to tell the same stories and characters over and over again. There are better shows that do way more with the medium.

There's nothing original about a shounen series like this, but sometimes there doesn't have to be. It feels like a familiar sort of swashbuckling adventure romp (as a loose adaptation would) energized by the typical Power of Friendship that brings protagonists back together.

First of all, I have to say I am a fan of the manga which this anime was derived from. Overall I think this is a "okie" adaptation and I gave it a overall score of 8 out of 10. 
Following this I will give a detailed breakdown of how I feel about the adaptation compared to the manga.
Story: 8
Story is exactly the same as the manga, only some minor details in the scenes are edited. The story of "Magi" is a story of grand adventure using a paraody of the characters and the background setting from the classic "Tales of the arabian nights" stories.Most people would be famililar with names such as "Aladdin and the magic lamp, Ali Baba and the forty thieves, Sinbad and the Tales of the seven seas"


Magic lamps, spells, flying magic carpets, djinns, deserts, bandits, adventure & danger... all the iconic objects and elements from "Tales of the arabian nights" make it into the story of "Magi". 

My only gripe with this anime adaptation was that the emotional parts of the story from the manga does not have the same weight as they do in the anime. It could be due the fast pacing of the anime episodes. 

The drama and emotional, dark, gritty background stories on each the characters was part of what made the plot of manga "Magi" so attractive. The characters are flawed and almost everyone has a bit of dark history, the history makes the actions of each character believable and the reader/viewer can relate and understand the motivations of each character.

However in the anime the scenes which deplict their histories seem to be rushed and this reduces the overall weight and effect of the emotional drama.


Art: 8

Bright colours in the anime are really well done and the characters are animated almost exactly as they were in the manga, in a bit of a childish, immature way. The colours really bring out the beauty of ancient arabian culture as if you would want to see them if you could travel back into time. 

The childish character animations bring out part of the comedy aspect, the anime doesn't take itself too seriously, and this gives the viewer a nostalgic feeling of adventure & discovery that they had when they were less than 10 years old.


Sound: 9

The voice actors for each of the characters fit the characters perfectly, except maybe for Aladdin. A voice actor with a more childish voice might have been a better match for Aladdin, but overall the current voice actor does a decent job.

The opening and especially the ending song really brings out the childlike sense of adventure that is invoked when a person gets involved watching "Magi". 

Just listening to the childish voices singing the chorus of the ending song, watching scenes of Aladdin and gang travelling, being wowed visiting the different cultures all across the land, gives the viewer the feeling of grand adventure, innocent wide eyed amazement at discovering new cultures and seeing new lands. This bundle of positive feelings is really a good summary of what a viewer feels when watching "Magi" :)


Characters: 8

Like I mentioned in the story review section, the characters are well thought out. Each character has a distinct personality, flaws and elaborate backstory with a little bit of darkness splashed in. This makes the characters believable, the motivations sound, and the audience can understand, relate and connect to the characters. 

I only wished the anime could spend a little more time and effort and add more weight to the dark backstory sections (as compared to the manga). A first time anime viewer of "Magi" compared to the manga reader would probably not be as invested in the characters.


Enjoyment: 8

Pretty enjoyable anime overall as it conveys the beauty and sense of adventure from the manga version of "Magi" very well. So far whenever a new anime episode is subbed and released each week I have been eagerly watching and anticipating how the story from the manga is going to be adapted into anime.


Overall: 8

A decent anime adaption of "Magi" from manga to anime. The songs, voice acting are almost a perfect fit for the characters. The anime remains very faithful to the story and filler free (thank goodness!). My only gripe is that they seem to breeze through the story at a pretty fast pace and don't spend enough time elaborating on the darker backstory sections of the characters. I would actually recommend reading the manga over watching the anime. And if a person wants to do both, read the manga first before watching the anime, enjoy!

Note: This will be a review of both seasons.
Overview:
I'm assuming everyone's heard about "One Thousand and One Nights" at some point in their lives, right? You know, the collection of Arabian folk tales following the adventures of Aladdin, Alibaba, Sinbad and many other figures and their various adventures and searches for treasure. "Magi: The Labyrinth of Magic" and its sequel "The Kingdom of Magic" is a shounen fantasy anime heavily influenced by these very stories, yet still manages to emerge as a fresh and unique story in its own right. How does it manage this, I hear you ask? Well, you're about to find out.
Story& World (8.5/10):

The story is quite complex, which makes it difficult to describe concisely, but I'm going to try anyway. Basically, it follows Aladdin, a ten-year-old boy and traveller who lives in an alternate recreation of the ancient Old World, where all living beings possess an essence known as Rukh, which can only be seen by incredibly powerful magicians known as Magi, one of whom, as fate would have it, is Aladdin. There are also several magic castles known as Dungeons and each of them is the lair of a powerful magic being called a Djinn. Individuals that manage to overcome the trials of a Dungeon and earn the allegiance of its Djinn become known as Dungeon Capturers, gaining the ability to use its powers infused in a personal item of theirs known as a Metal Vessel as well all the treasure that lies within the Dungeon. In the first episode alone, we're introduced to not only Aladdin, but a teenage boy named Alibaba and a slave girl called Morgiana, the latter of whom is part of a mysterious and super-strong warrior tribe known as the Fanalis. These two quickly become not only Aladdin's travelling companions, but also his closest friends.


But, to be honest, I've barely scratched the surface, as things just get more and more complicated as time goes on, which is no bad thing, really. As far as anime settings go, this one is incredibly unique, as no other anime I know is set in Arabian lands and the world-building is brilliant. The dungeons are quite interesting and no two look even remotely the same. And, unlike almost every treasure-hunting story I know, the heroes actually manage to walk away with some treasure and relics instead of having to sacrifice them for a greater good. How about that?


The series starts off as a rather light-hearted action-comedy adventure, but things start to get a lot darker and more serious in the Magnostadt arc, which takes up the entire final quarter of the series and deals heavily with dark themes like racism and poverty. All of this being said, the story is not without its problems. Some of the settings are very underused since we see little of them, which is always a risk when creating such a vast world. The story can also feel very dragged out at times, with many scenes going on for much longer than they should. Considering the series adapts about 4 or 5 chapters per episode, I can only imagine how slow the pacing of the manga is. The second season also ends on a huge cliffhanger, which will leave people begging for a third season. That being said, these problems are pretty small, and overall the story is one of the highlights of the series.


Art & Animation (8/10):

The art is, for a lack of a better word, generic. It doesn't look awful, but it doesn't look amazing either. The character designs are rather simple and the environments look just like those of many other anime. There's also a lot of deranged animation in the series, which I have never been a fan of as I've seen several anime that do comedy just fine without it. There are some really good effects, such as the Rukh and the magic effects, but overall the visuals don't do anything that we haven't seen a hundred times.


Sound & Dialogue (8.5/10):

The soundtrack isn't anything to write home about, but it's well-done and fits the series very well. Some of the opening and ending themes are great as well, most notably "Hikari" and "Eden". The voice acting is excellent, with special mentions going to Erica Mendez as Aladdin (the role that got her noticed) and Cristina Vee as Morgiana, though I don't think I found a single voice in the series that I didn't like. The dialogue is quite plain, for the most part, but that means that the memorable lines stand out all the more.


Characters (8.5/10):

The characters are another one of this series's strengths. There's an awful lot of them so it would take forever to go through them all, so for now I'll focus on the main ones. Aladdin is considerably younger than a standard shonen protagonist and that always has its risks, since young boys have a reputation for being brats. Thankfully, I can say that Aladdin is nothing like that. He's actually very wise and mature for his age, which is largely the result of him being a Magi, which grants him access to Solomon's Wisdom. He's also surprisingly perverted and manly for his age, having a tendency to bury his face into womans' breasts, which leads to some downright hilarious moments. He starts off very naive, but after lots of experience and training in magic, he grows into a very wise and powerful magician with a strong moral compass.


However, if I were to pick a favourite character in the series, it would have to be Morgiana, the slave girl who Aladdin and Alibaba rescue at the beginning from Jamil, a two-bit slaver and the first villain of the series. She is a Fanalis, a very powerful and clearly not-human warrior tribe with legs and feet stronger than any kind of footwear, so needless to say, she is a total badass. She feels indebted to Aladdin and Alibaba for saving her and so is determined to repay that debt. Despite her stoic nature, she soon proves herself to be just as kind as Aladdin, being unable to turn her back on anyone in danger. Having been a slave for pretty much her whole life, the concept of being able to do whatever she wants is pretty much completely alien to her, and so part of her character development involves learning the meaning of freedom, which is very interesting to watch. Unfortunately, her screentime is quite limited during the second half of the second season, which admittedly takes away from an otherwise fantastic arc.


Last up, we have Alibaba, a teenage boy who becomes Aladdin's best friend and is later revealed to be the adopted son of a prince. Initially, he suffers from very low self-confidence due to the tragic loss of his father at a young age and a falling-out with his best friend Cassim, a gang leader whom he comes into conflict with early in the series. I was able to relate to him quite strongly, since I have a lot of insecurities myself. He and Aladdin have quite a bit in common, since Alibaba is also very mature for his age (what he went through will do that to you) and the two often go out "babe-hunting". Overall, though, I found him to be the least compelling of the three.


The other characters are numerous, with various people from several different nations. Notable examples include Sinbad, an extremely powerful king and the capturer of seven (yes, seven) dungeons, Hakuryuu, a prince from a foreign land who bears an uncanny resemblance to Prince Zuko from "Avatar: The Last Airbender", and Judar, another Magi who can basically be summed up as an evil Aladdin. The reason for the not-so-glowing score is that I felt there were a lot of characters who could have used more screen-time, particularly Hakuei, Hakuryuu's older sister who I found to be a lot more likable than her brother, though anymore would be a spoiler.


Enjoyment (8.5/10):

Pacing issues notwithstanding, "Magi" manages to be a very enjoyable series, with plenty of action and comedy to keep you engaged throughout the 50 episodes. Even when it descends into darker territory in the Magnostadt arc, it never feels heavy-handed since the dark elements are handled very meaningfully, instead of feeling overdone like so many other anime. There were some moments when I felt like yawning, but they were few and far between.


Overall:

"Magi" is a series I can definitely say I enjoyed watching, and a brilliant reimagining of old tales. It's hard not to put it in the same boat as "Hunter X Hunter" or "Fairy Tail", but to dismiss it just because of that would be a mistake. The story is deep and interesting, the world is vast and the characters are fantastic. Even if you aren't a particularly big fan of shounens, this is an anime worth seeing.

MAGI: THE LABYRINTH OF MAGIC: Incredible world building, poor storytelling
I saw a lot of potential as early as the first episode because the author did a good job on world building. The Magi world is just so huge that there is a lot of room for the story to branch out -- and it did branch out. It talked about the mysterious powers of djinns and magic in general; about political warfare that led to slavery, poverty, and death; about the rising Kou Empire and its diplomatic attempts to rise further into power; about the mysterious organization that wants to plunge the world into darkness.All of these are tackled in a mere twenty-five episodes -- and that’s not a good thing.


That’s the main problem I have with the series. Everything is so fast-paced that it spoils the important moments. There’s not enough time to raise the tension, so every conflict feels to be resolved prematurely. The story is just too broad to be expanded in such a short period of time. And, I must add, that the story has been somewhat spoiled because of this.


As for the characters, I must admit that I find them to be very well designed. Each character has its own unique aura and personality. However, the abruptness of the story is so problematic that it even fails to expand these characters’ depths well -- so most of them seem flat despite being uniquely designed. Aside from that, one of the main characters, Alibaba, has actions that are really not justifiable. His emotional tendencies are not established well, so they appear to be executed just to move the story further.


Perhaps the redeeming factor of this series is really the imaginative world it has established. It is just so interesting that, despite the storytelling being awkward, I still continued watching, for I wanted to explore the incredible world before me. What makes it even more interesting is the fact that there are so many questions left unanswered in the season finale. It keeps me guessing. And it is further proof that the author did a good job in creating the fictional world. So, despite its flaws, Magi: The Labyrinth of Magic is still a watchable series. It already has the raw material to be a great anime. The only thing that needs some improvement is the storytelling.

First Impressions:
Magi has potential. Other subject matters have been woven into the plot, but simply speaking, Magi is a re-wrapping of the typical shounen action genre. The fresh Arabian setting is an enjoyable reprieve from the sea of sameness.
The early episodes give an impression that this might become an adventure/dungeon crawler type, but half way dives into the kingdom/rebellion zone. Being a fan of the latter, I was glad. Unfortunately the writing is still immature for the subject matter and doesn't completely meet the need. Episode 10's action is abruptly brought to and end by the timely arrival of an anime trope character, characters thatonly until then had 1 or 2 shots in the background from forth to spill all the beans, and Alibaba's reluctant hero nature in 12 leaves much to be desired.


The music is good; OP/END are catchy and don't prompt me to skip them immediately and the BGM makes good use of eastern instruments that chime in every now and then. Animation and art are crisp and does the job.


Magi has potential. There is much here to like and possible love. Twelve episodes isn't enough to judge how this anime will become in the future. A couple missteps have left me wanting, but I'm hopeful that Magi will become something I can get excited about.


A tentative 7.

Magi: The Labryrinth of Magic has great potential but loses all appeal and turns into yet another generic anime. The Middle Eastern, Afrian, and Mediterranean influences on the setting and character costumes were refreshing and the animation reflected that. Moreso, the characters had decent potential (slave girl turned free, mysterious magic boy, and lower-class suck up) but by the end they were all lifeless tropes. Some of the story elements (like those dungeon towers) should have been given more focus and others (like the dragging stale political drama arc) less. 
This show is afflicted by the same elements that haunt all other generic shows: theheroic MC's speech which changes the hearts of the antagonists, yelling random words to form magic, yelling louder to gain more power, etc. No coherent or consistent rules in the world leads to no "danger" for the characters. Just deus ex machina and believing power.  \n\n
Save your time, skip this.

I've always enjoyed the Arabian Nights theme/mythology, so I was actually a little surprised that I'd never even heard of this anime until I randomly spotted it while browsing Netflix. It's a fun show, that touches on some interesting themes while also falling into familiar shounen territory.
Story - 7/10:
I found the story to be a little hit or miss. There were a couple arcs that were really enjoyable, and some that stagnated a bit. The story starts off interestingly enough, with a young Aladdin eating melons in the back of Ali Baba's cart. It sets off a bit of an odd couple partnership, but itworks very nicely. 


The setting is interesting enough, a play on the ancient middle east. There are a series of djinns that inhabit dungeons and can grant "dungeon capturers" powerful magical items. Aladdin himself is a magi, a sort of wise man (or wise child?) who has incredible magical powers and is sent to the earth in order to choose his "king's candidate" - the idea being that eventually the world will unite under the rule of a single king or leader.


My main issue with the story was that it felt like the show wasn't sure what it wanted to be. Half the time it's your typical shounen battle series, with long drawn-out fight sequences that spawn multiple episodes, and your standard "love/friendship" conquers all conclusions to conflicts. But it also dives pretty deep into ideas of slavery and leadership that go a little beyond what you'd normally find in a shounen. Some of the ideas seem a little mature (as an example, one of the plot lines involves a money-devaluation scheme to bankrupt a country - I'm not sure how much a young viewer would be able to resonate with ideas like that). 


Art - 8/10:


I thought the art was well done. I was thrown off a few times when I literally swore I was watching Fairy Tail. I know they're both A-1 productions, but the art style is identical. They must use the same staff of artists, it's really uncanny. Luckily, I enjoy Fairy Tail's art, so this works for me. The animation could be a bit better, but it's about on par with most shounen I've seen.


Sound - 8/10:


I watched the English dub. Most of the voice acting was solid. A couple choices seemed a bit out of place. The music was good, if not great. All around, pretty solid effort.


Character - 8/10:


I enjoyed the character work in the show. Given that it's only 25 episodes of what I presume is a fairly long-running story, there's not a ton of development. What development is there is a bit on the nose and repetitive - like Ali Baba getting cursed and having to overcome negative emotions, right after having to do basically the same thing in the conflict with his childhood friend. The same can be said of Aladdin, who basically knows nothing about being a Magi, and his development is a little heavy-handed.


What really works, as is often the case in shounen, is the wide variety of likeable and interesting minor characters. I'm not sure if you'd consider Sinbad to be minor here, but he's a great character. Many of the people in his crew, or those from the Ko Empire, are intriguing additions. Child characters are often hit or miss for me, but I liked Aladdin. I'm very much looking forward to seeing how he develops his magic prowess as he comes to understand more and more about himself. 


Enjoyment - 9/10:


I don't know what the metrics are for gauging enjoyment, but I always find the pace that I watch a show goes a long way to telling me how much I'm enjoying it. I have a lot of hobbies that I spend time on, and I'm putting off other things because I just really want to watch the next episode (or five) of whatever show I'm into at the moment, that's a big plus. I moved through the first season of this show pretty quick, and I'm eager to dive into season two.


Overall - 8/10:


Like I said, sometimes I felt like this show had a bit of an identity crisis, flopping between standard shounen fare aimed at teenage males and ideas that seemed slightly more mature. There was even brief nudity now and then, which is unusual. The battle scenes were fun without being too long (my primary complaint with shounen is that the fight scenes last ten episodes/chapters - I know I'm in the minority there, as a lot of people prefer those super-long battles).  


I'm looking forward to diving into season two, and maybe checking out the manga afterwards. If the story starts to lean more towards the mature issues and shows a bit of originality, it could be quite an impressive anime.

Magi is a weird one. I really enjoyed it on many occasions but there are so many fundamental flaws that I feel I can't ignore. You will notice it wears the face of a good show with politics, fantasy, drama and fighting but it lacks consistency, depth and most importantly: continuity. In many other situations, these things wouldn't matter all that much to me. I overlooked the lack of these things in Fairy Tail, Kill la Kill and Overlord, just to name a few, but the reason I take offence to this anime's lack of these is because it leaks into the other aspects ofthis show that desperately need them. Without spoiling, I will say that this issue causes massive decay for aspects such as risk and development in terms of the story. 


Now, of course, there are reasons that I think these things but I will get into them later. What I am most concerned about is how I came ever so close to dropping this anime and, keep in mind, I have only ever dropped one anime (and that was because it simply wasn't compatible with my preferred style of story-telling). Upon starting Magi: LoM, I got some very mixed messages about where the story was going and where the true enemy lied... but.... this is going into story territory, so I may as well just cut to that.




Story -

As I was saying. The story was relatively hard to grasp at first. I'm not saying that it was difficult to understand, just that it struggled to lay the foundation. We start off with Alibaba, who is portrayed as a humble and aspiring person who thanks to the anime's designated 'special character', Aladdin, gets on the wrong side of some rich people and ends up going on this short little quest to get a nice weapon and the freedom to go on an adventure. Here is where we find our first problem, the second that this little arc ends, you might as well completely extinguish it from your memory. Despite a few knacks that could easily be ironed out by an extra episode or two in the Balbadd arc, the first arc, which is integral to making a good first impression and gaining the interest of the viewer, only serves to get Alibaba a weapon. This is especially true if you consider that despite the fact they meet in the first arc, they go through the same meet and greet process as if they need to relearn each other's names! It gets incredibly tedious and it's not until episode 8 or 9 that I actually decided that it may be picking up and resisted the temptation to watch something else.


Of course, this scrutiny is quite temperamental. There are many people out there who may think that this first arc is essential to the pacing of the story or the development of the characters. I would disagree because the story tends to pick up the pace anyway and most of the character development ends up happening later on in the season. But, as I said, this can be subject to opinion.


One thing I will praise the story for is its ability to provide a good villain. While he may be hard to describe due to his conspicuous nature, he never really shows a moment of weakness, which sends a powerful message and actually had me admiring him. Additionally, there are a number of other factors such as politics, schemes, treachery as well as a few psychological elements, but it ends up being wasted due to one simple mistake: They made the good guys too OP. Initially, the size and force of the enemy seemed like a worthy opponent, maybe even a stronger one, but it all fell flat on its face when half of the guys were like - "I'm bored now" and just win with one swing. Had they executed this right then they probably could have made it look bad ass, but all we ever see is them succeed so it  ended up being VERY anticlimactic, not to mention disappointing.




Art and Sound -

Both of these elements have a very 'old Egyptian' vibe to them. You knew that you were in 'the old world' (as Wikipedia would put it) and I think that these elements did a very good job of depicting that. I'm very reluctant to give either of these categories a higher score than the story that they were depicting but I think that Magi at least deserves credit where its due. The environment and its cultures are very well laid out as well as the magics of the various cast members. Sound wise, I enjoyed it. I found that there were a number of moments where the intense music would often play up a scene to be better than it actually was but that's more of a problem on the stories part. Regardless of your taste in music or opinion of the story, I think that it shouldn't go unmentioned how well these two played their roles.




Character-

This was a hard one for me as well. Much like the story, there are some elements that were just shallow and lame while others were deep and interesting. Starting off with the latter: I loved Alibaba as a character (at least after episode 9), he was very determined and adamant to do what he thought was right while still being troubled with doubt and his previous failures. This may seem like standard stuff but the way it was presented enforced his leadership personality and I think it did wonders for him, his relationships and in some cases, the story. As a stand alone character, I think Alibaba would probably be around a 9 for me. Other characters with similar developmental traits consist of Morgiana, Judar and Cassim.


On the flip side, we have characters that I hated, like Aladdin, who was extremely shallow, arrogant and didn't really do much besides act as a conduit for Alibaba's authority and was sometimes a trump card in battle. They do attempt to make him seem wise and they do throw in a bit of development here and there but in the end its all for nought because of one stupid idea: Let's make this 10-year-old boy a tit loving pervert. Now, boobage is common in anime, as is the young perversion, but when you try and mix comedy relief with the 'wise man' responsibilities provided to you by the plot and then try to seriously develop that character, you're almost doomed to fail. The only way you can avoid failure as an outcome would be to execute it flawlessly. Magi... did not.... not... even... close. He was also pretty useless at times until later on in the season when he suddenly becomes OP, which, as you know, still doesn't turn out well.





Enjoyment-

I hate to have to say that I loved this show despite the fact there is so much wrong with it. It's like having an angel and a devil on each shoulder except the angel doesn't really serve a purpose except to encourage pandering and fanboying. My enjoyment of Magi derives from the latter half of the story. My distaste for Magi derives from the former half of the story. It's certainly a dilemma.




Conclusion-

I recommend you watch this. If you agree with me, you'll find it hard to trudge through the first 8-9 episodes but if you can make it past that then you really get into the good stuff and hopefully, the transgressions that I described earlier can be shifted to the back of your head. For me, unfortunately, I'm as pedantic as I'll ever be and as a result, I'm going to have to maintain my position on this show with all of my scrutinies at my back.


If I were not as nit-picky as I am, I would probably have given this show an 8. That Just goes to show that my reviews are usually one step up from casually subjective and that you should probably read another review, or just take the plunge and go for it.
